1.content:
As I step into the museum, the lights come on automatically revealing row upon row of carved granite pedestals. On top of each pedestal is a single object, which is covered by a clear glass dome. I walk to the first pedestal, look at the object under the dome, and a tear rolls down my cheek because this item belonged to a long deceased family member. I turn my back on that pedestal and go to the one directly across from it, where I find another item that links me to someone out of my past. I look at the item and smile because this object belonged to an old friend I have not seen or heard from in years.

I walk along the row for a few minutes, look at the item on each pedestal, and either smile or cry because of the person the item belonged to. I walk back to one of the pedestals, reach out my right hand, and touch the glass dome covering it. The dome dissolves allowing me to touch and then pick up the item. As I hold the object, memories flood my mind.
1.title: Entering the Museum

choices: A Photo of a Man in a Military Uniform
A Coffee Mug with a Holiday Decoration
11.content:
I pick up the gold plated antique cigarette case and memories of my maternal grandfather flood my mind. The case is probably about two or three inches wide and four or five inches long (I could be over estimating the size because I don't smoke), with ridges across the length of the case. I open it and look inside, there I find two metal spring pedals to hold the cigarettes in the case. On one of the pedals I find the words "Parker of London Made in USA." I close the case, caress it, and then smile and cry at the same time.

I remember seeing Grandpa carrying this case when he wore his Sunday go to meeting suite. Most of the time Grandpa wore overalls or work clothes, but when he went to church, a funeral, or a business appointment he wore a suite. At those times, he carried it in his breast pocket and, on Sunday, when he was shooting the bull (as he called gossiping with his friends) in the church yard or parking lot, he would take it out and offer his friends a smoke.

I cry, as I think about those times, knowing that it was the rolled cigarettes that caused his lung cancer, but I can't bring myself to destroy this object that links me to my father figure. Therefore, I place it reverently back on the pedestal, watching as the glass dome reassembles over the cigarette case. Then I walk to the next pedestal to fined...
11.title: Grandpa's Cigarette Case

choices: a glass jar with words Pennant Peanuts, 5 cents, decorating the sides
a blue face towel with the letter "M" written in script across the front
a single blue butterfly pinned to a black velvet pillow
111.content:
Under a dusty glass dome, is a sepia colored photo of a man in a military uniform. Something about the man catches my eye so I reach out to release the old photo from its glass prison. The glass dome melts away and displayed on a ornate, scroll-worked, black metal stand is a tintype photo. I pull the metal photograph gently from the stand and hold it up so I can examine it better.

I remember my Gramps used to have a thick, red, felt type photo album full of photos such as these. When I was a child, I loved to pour over the photographs. My grandfather did not know who the people in the photographs were. The book had been handed down for hundreds of years. Unfortunately, the photo album was lost when the garage it was kept in was hit by a drunk driver and was demolished.

Gramps had taught me that tintypes were photographs made by creating a negative on a thin sheet of metal coated then processed with painting, lacquering, or enameling then coated with a photographic emulsion. They were around from the 1850s to the 1940s. The process was quick and the use of iron metal sheets meant the photographs could be done cheaply. This was perfect for photographs taken in the battle fields.

So, who is this young soldier in the photo? He is standing with a group of other men, around a campfire. Tents are spread out behind them. Several of the men are sprawled on the ground and drinking from what looks like bottles and cups. Most of the men are laughing, but some of them have stern looks on their faces. They all have beards except for the subject of the photograph.

The soldier has what looks like stick-straight, shoulder length, black hair. His eyes are dark and almond shaped. He seems to be peering off into the distance, away from the photographer. Does he wonder what will happen to him next? What horrors will he experience? Will the laughing men around him be back at the campsite the next morning?

The sepia tones reveal darker skin and a prominent nose. He is standing alone, closer to the camera. I think back to the verbal history of my family my grandfather told me. I didn't know about any of my relatives being in the civil war. If they were, they would have fought for the north. The uniforms didn't look right. The one the soldier in the photograph is wearing is a loose tunic like top with a vest over it. Looped across the vest is a belt full of big bullets. Light colored, loose pants are tucked into knee-high moccasins.

Moccasins? I look more carefully. The soldier in the photograph is wearing a bandana and is carrying some sort of long-arm.

Could the soldier in the photograph be one of my American Indian ancestors? Could he be a scout for the American troops during the Apache wars? Why is he with this group of laughing men and why does he look so lost?

I put the photograph reverently back in its stand and watch the dome magically cover it over again. The dust is gone.

I wander around the museum of linking objects and wish the album and my grandfather were still around, and I could solve the mystery of the man in the military uniform.

Up ahead are more pedestals with objects to discover. I head for the one on the left and find...
111.title: A Photo of a Man in a Military Uniform

112.content:
.....A coffee mug - I recognise it. It is a large, chunky type mug, the type he always used to fill to the brim with milky coffee which sloshed over the sides on to the tarpaulin as he carried it through to the lounge where we would be watching some cheesy teen horror flick on the telly or playing "Final Fantasy".

I touch the glass gently and it disappears, leaving the receptacle free to be lifted from the pedestal. It is a standard white mug with the Spanish flag printed on one side and a map of Tenerife on the other. I remember him choosing it idly whilst I agonised between souvenir tea towels, aprons and egg cups for my friends and relatives back home.

Tenerife - the holiday to begin the holiday revolution! I was so green back then, phoning up an agency I found online and jabbering away. How long ago it seemed now!

I look at the mug, turning it in my hands, remembering how I built a sandcastle on the beach whilst we swigged sunkissed drinks from plastic cups. I was thinner then, I looked good in a bikini. I bought an inflatable crocodile and we went croc surfing in the sea, under an azure sky. In my minds eye, a girl in a red dress and a man in tie dyed cut-offs look at me and smile. I smile back.

I return the mug to the pedestal and turn to the next one......
112.title: A Coffee Mug with a Holiday Decoration

choices: Head into another part of the museum
1123.content:
Every object releases memories. Some make me laugh; some, cry; some leave me confused; some are frightening. After one of the latter, I wander quickly down the hall to an archway trying to escape the strong personal emotions that each object triggers.

Around a corner, I enter a dim hall. There's a glow from between two columns that pulls me in. I stop. In an alcove are framed items on the wall. Two needlepoint pictures. Pheasants.

They are my mom's. She made them. They hung in my parents home, and now I am there again looking across the wood dining table and chairs.

The three part casement window to my left lets in the warm glow as the backyard appears beyond. It's shallow, a dozen feet deep. A rise at the back, a few feet tall, leads up to the field of grass or wheat that dissolves into the distance. The rock garden sits on the hillside, more rocks than flowers. Only the phlox thrives creeping over stones in several spots. Its small blossoms the only color besides brown and gray.

In front of the garden now, to my left is the back patio. The black-and-brown mutt looks over his shoulder before he dashes off into the neighborhood of ranch-style homes. A dog chain hooked to a stake in the yard has another dog. I release the little brown dachshund who leads me back inside to the kitchen.

Corner windows over the sink show me where I just came. Small shelves hold knickknacks by the windows with cupboards extending down the walls and over the stove. Past the fridge is back to the dining room and the pictures.

My attention, though, turns to the the window shelves by the sink - a crystal squirrel, life size, sitting up. Its silhouette catches a sunbeam and sparkles a rainbow into my eyes, glistening brilliance surrounds it floating in front of me until everything fades.

I'm back in the main hall, a pedestal before me. Light points down from the ceiling through the dome and is scattered by the crystal creature inside.

Again, I back away, but this time I amble slowly through the hall.
1123.title: Another hall of the museum

choices: Do I find another item that brings back the past
11233.content:
I rest on a bench by a large cement door.
I think of life past that I have no more.
Wondering if something was left unsaid
How did this memory come into my head.

Could I have been kinder to a mother in need,
Of sympathy for a child who she could not feed?
Is there an anger I have yet to uncover?
Is it a question of do I or do I not love her?

I bring myself back from a moment of thought
Only to move forward on a search to be taught.
I move on quietly with a need to know more
As I think and walk by the large cement door.
11233.title: Something else

choices: Move to the next item of your choice
Choose a trailer or a religious object
12.content:
I pick up the large red heart-shaped candy box and I smile. Not just a little smile but a big one that stretches across my face. This smile turns into a laugh. Withdrawing a tissue from my pocket I wipe the tears from my eyes. You see this reminds me of my father-in-law. He was a tight-fisted soul. It could have been that being raised by a single mother home and the brunt of all the meanness his siblings fostered at his expense, he clung to what was his and what he paid for. I saw this in evidence during the time my mother-in-law was alive. Something changed when she died. He retired and bought a little trailer and drove from branch church to branch church offering his hands to whatever needed done.
He landed in Portland, Oregon about the time the headquarters began to build a new church across the street from the Tabernacle and campgrounds. During this time he found a girlfriend and after months of dating he asked her to marry him, much to his children's surprise. We'd heard it was yes, but she had some conditions I guess my father-in-law determined to change. Around Valentine's day he bought her a red heart-shaped box of chocolates. It must have been a little while before the actual day and he pilfered one. This left a hole so he adjusted the rest of the little brown paper cups to fill in. He slipped out another and then another until he couldn't hide the fact anymore and so just went ahead and ate all the chocolates in the box. Now he had no candies in the box to give his sweetheart. Not to be undone, he wrote this note and taped it to the bottom of the inside of the box. It read: "My heart is empty like this box of chocolates." I don't think she was too happy to get that gift on Valentine's day. It was just a short while later we found out the engagement was off. She didn't want to travel around the country in a beat up old trailer when she had a nice comfortable home.
I place the dome back over the red box with its ruffle band and "Happy Valentine's Day" stamped in gold. With a last little chuckle I move on down the aisle.
12.title: Red Heart-Shaped Candy Box

choices: I attempt to pocket the pin and move on.
14.content:
My brother and I are running through our Mothers freshly hung laundry lines. Both of our shirts are covered in small wooden pinchers.

Clothespin was a game we came up with on one of those drowsy summer days when it was too windy to swim but too hot to sit inside. The object: stick as many pins on the other person as possible before time ran out. Mom's yells for us to 'quit messin' her good clean clothes' was usually our end of round buzzer.

On this particular day I only had 2 pins to his six. I probably should have taken pity on my lil bro and let him win, but then what kind of man would he be today? Tired of the game and the chase I tackled him to the ground and pinched both clips to the front of his shirt. I may have accidentally got some skin, hazards of the sport.

I ran away from his yelps and cries of 'CHEATER'! The grin on my face well earned.
14.title: A Wooden Clothespin

choices: A Photo of a Happy Family
15.content:
I look at the object and smile because lying on the pedestal is Mama's pink prayer beads. I reach out my right hand and the glass dome disappears, allowing me to pick up the string of prayer beads. There are 95 pink plastic beads on a thin double cord with two red beads and a six-sided metal bead at the end (after a knot separating them from the pink beads). After the three beads there is another knot with a gold tassel on the end.

I laugh and cry, as I remember Mom's angelic voice echoing through the house each morning when she chanted God's Most Great Name. I can remember standing outside her open bedroom door, watching her use the beads to count each phrase she intoned. I hesitate, for a moment, considering taking the beads with me when I leave the museum, but decide against it. I sigh placing them back on the pedestal, knowing that they belong in this museum of memories, and watch the glass reform above the beads.
15.title: My Mother's Prayer Beads

choices: Do I go home and relay this experience to a loved one.
Do I go to the cematary and have a talk with my brother.
Do I continue walking through the museum of memories.
154.content: The small blue book titled "Journal" causes my heart to leap when I note the year of my greatest loss. I open the pages and tears form and begin to flow with the opening words. "Today my brother died." As the tears begin to diminish and my vision clears I continue my memory walk. I retrace the phone call as my niece told me, "Auntie, Daddy is gone, he died last night of a heart attack" I heard my silent scream inside my head as I placed the small journal back in it's place, knowing that this walk through the museum of memories is not all going to be easy.
154.title: A Personal Journal

155.content:
I pick up the small, silver ring that lies on a plush red cushion on a pedestal. It feels cool in my fingers and I slip it on. It goes right into place and sits there, three tiers of beauty upon my hand. Tears sparkle in my eye. It was a ring owned by my Grandma and one she sought to pass on when she passed on. It's a reminder of all the time spent with that wonderful woman, the smiles, the happiness, the ice cream! Oh the ice cream. It was always served in a soda float following a gorgeous Sunday dinner (which followed a breakfast of sugar on toast). Oh how I miss her.

I almost don't want to put the ring back. It's a part of her that will keep me connected forever, but I know I must. As I place the ring back onto the cushion gently, I sigh and move on. On the next pedestal I see...
155.title: Something Else

choices: a photograph frame with an old sepia picture inside
1551.content: It's an old silver pocket-watch on a chain, that my grandpa used to wear with the chain looped through a buttonhole on his waistcoat, and hidden behind a red handkerchief in his waistcoatpocket. I pick it up and weigh it in my hands, the cool metal smooth against my skin. It seems larger than it did when I was six, and needed both hands to hold it. He always had strange things hidden about his clothing, like a coin in the toe of his shoe 'In case I need to use a public phone box,' he'd say, or a builder's measuring tape in his trouser pocket. 'You never know when you'll need to measure something,' he'd say, and usually whip it out and measure me, exclaiming to the precise millimetre over how much I'd grown. I never got tired of that. Carefully, I put the watch back on its pedestal,and slip the glass case over the top. It's a good place for my grandpa's watch. Safe.
1551.title: Another piece of jewelry

choices: An iridescent glass ball attached to an ornate stick
An hour glass with glowing, colored sand
15512.content:
I held the faded portrait in my hand. There she was, it was true, I had proof that my great grandmother gave birth to twins. Not that she was holding them, but this was a wedding picture of Emily and Jonathan Frasier and it was real.
I touched the familiar face of the woman, it was almost the same features I saw every day in my own mirror. Next to this photo lay one of my grandmother's wedding. The resemblance to her mother and myself felt uncanny.
However, it was this resemblance that began a search to bring two families together who ever knew about each other.
I smiled at the photo's lying on the table. What fate brought me to the Oregon coast, to a Bed and Breakfast run by my mother's cousins? I remember the moment I drove up to the front of the house and felt the recognition. This house was an exact replica of my own grandmother's house on the East Coast. What transpired after that, intertwined into a story that had divided not just my grandparents, but the respect of a young lawyer for his ancestor.
15512.title: a photograph frame with an old sepia picture in...

choices: a bright yellow and orange popcorn popper
1552.content:
Under a glass dome, a chlld's hardcover book is illuminated under the bright museum lights. I am excited to see probably the last remaining copy of my favorite book as a youngster titled "The Adventures of Starbeem and Re-Koil" by D.J. Donovan, written in 1967, one printing. I held my hand over the glass dome and eagerly held the book in my hands again for the first time since I was five years old.

This edition of the book looks well loved, much as I loved my book. There is the smiling face of Re-Koil, the orange space dog with three eyes, who is a bit of a dunce but a good friend of Starbeem, the space cat star of the book series. Starbeem stares out at me from the cover. She is a beautiful space cat, black with bright blue eyes and a star on the tip of her tail. Her friends are Webby, the space bird and Wilfred, the baby space dragon.

The book was printed by a private press out in Ohio. My parents found it for me at a Book Fair. When I open the book and trace the illustrations with my fingers gently, I think of the thrill of the chase at all the book fairs my parents would take me to as a child.

My parents would give us ten dollars and let us loose in the warehouse that ran the book fair. This was the nineteen sixties and seventies, when parents allowed their children more freedom. They dropped us off in the children's section and went browsing adult books on their own. There were loads of other kids there too, most parked on the floor, lost to the fantasy worlds children live in with books.

I found Starbeem. Her face and starred tail greatly appealed to me. I could never have a cat for a pet, since I am deadly allergic to them, therefore, a cat was what I wanted most of all.

I paid for the book and a couple of "Archie and Veronica" comic books and my parents drove us home.

With colored pencils or watercolors, I would spend hours copying the illustrations from Starbeem's book. I still have a little notebook at my parent's home filled with my drawings. I wrote fan fiction based on Starbeem. The book's prose was probably written for a much older child, but it was the illustrations I was in love with.

Over time, I forgot about Starbeem. Now, here she is again. With a sigh of regret, I replace the book on the pedestal and the dome reappears around it. For a moment, I think I see Starbeem wink her black eyes at me and her starred tail twinkle.

Around the corner at the museum, another item catches my eye. It is..
1552.title: A book

1553.content:
Tabatha threw the napkin on the table. “I have had enough!” her voice low and mindful of the other restaurant patrons. “Diane, you don’t seem to care about our friendship. You find fault in everything I try to do to help you. If you don’t want me around anymore that is fine with me.” She stood and wove her way through the tables and out the door; leaving Diane to pay the bill.

Something fluttered at the edge of her vision and she turned to look. A coat stand with a beautiful black cloak, lined in red satin danced in the breeze. it. She looked up at the sign that read; The Museum of Linking Objects. Her feet moved to the door on their own volition.

“Good afternoon. I hope you're having a pleasant day.” The woman stood before her.

“I seem better at this moment. I was feeling a bit upset, but stepping into your shop I feel,” she paused. “Not peaceful but, content is the word.”

The woman smiled. “You have come to the right place." Tabatha's anger from the earlier conversation drained away. “Come, I think I know just the gift you need.”

“Oh, I didn’t come here to buy anything. I was just-“ She wondered why the woman thought she needed a gift?

“I know my dear, but you need to give this to your friend. It is something that she will come to appreciate.” Alice moved along the rows of wonderful dishware. She reached to pick up a cup decorated with ivy that formed a handle. “Don’t touch that!” Alice ordered.

Tabatha drew her hand back quickly and looked up. Alice smiled. “Not everything in my shop is meant to be handled. They are unique pieces and meant for a special person. Just as I have found for you. Here it is.”

Alice opened the box to reveal a beautiful silver hairbrush. It was nestled in a bed of fine blue satin, the color of royalty.

“Oh, that is beautiful.” But there would be no gifts to her former friend.

“I think you need to reconsider, this is a special brush that would mean something to the very person you thought of.” Alice shut the lid and pressed the ornate lock. The scent that had been so light before was almost overpowering her. She handed over her card.

“There you are my dear, take this to your friend. I'm sure when she has used your gift, you will find she is changed.”

Tabatha frowned. “Do you think so?"

Alice patted her hand as she reached for the handle of the bag. “You just give this to her. I am sure you'll be hearing from a changed person when she calls you.”

Tabatha left the gift with Diane’s houseman and drove home.

The phone ring woke her the next morning. “Hello?” her voice hoarse from sleep.

“Tabatha, how could you? You have to come here right away!” Diane’s crying, frantic voice assaulted her ear.

“What's wrong?”

“Just get here as fast as you can.” She heard a long wail and the phone went dead.

Donald, the houseman, let Tabatha in and pointed up. Diane's crying rang throughout the hallways.

She pushed Diane’s bedroom door open. Her firend sat at her dressing table. The silver brush in hand brushed her hair, or what was left of it. Long blond strands lay in a pile on the floor around her.

“I can’t stop brushing,” Diane wailed.

Appalled Tabatha reached for Diane's hand and tried to make it stop brushing. It was as if something controlled the brush. The repeated brushing continued in spite of Tabatha's firm grip.

“Where's Phil?” Tabatha asked about Diane's husband.

“He is out of town for a few weeks. Tabatha, what's happening to me? Why can’t I stop brushing my hair? It's all falling out.”

Tabatha found the ornate bag on the floor, the tissue ripped where Diane pulled it from its nest. She looked at the box Alice had placed the silver box in; it had nothing but designs on it. Nothing evil or sinister.

“I'll go back to where I bought it and see if I can find out how to make it stop.” Tabatha drove to the Museum but there were no lights inside.

After a moment she pulled the doobell cord and saw Alice walk toward the door.

“You've come to find how to reverse the spell of the silver brush.” She spoke after she opened the door and turned to walk away.
Tabatha followed “What happened? Is she cursed?”

“In a way. The things that became important to her cursed your friendship. One of those things was her beauty which she spent a fortune to enhance and keep. She thought nothing of your situation or what she could do to help those less fortunate than herself. The brush is showing how little these things mean.”

“But I caused it.” Tabatha felt horrified at what happened to her best friend. Diane may have needed an attitude adjustment, but she didn't deserved this degree of punishment.

“No, my dear, she could have returned the gift, left it as a thing of beauty to be observed, had it appraised and sold, giving the proceeds to the poor. But her selfishness overcame her."

“What does she have to do to stop all this and how do you keep reading my mind?” Tabatha added.

“Contrition. She must ask forgiveness from you and have a change of heart. She will need to see the error of her ways and want to change. When she does that the brushing will stop.” Alice ignored the latter question.

“That's all? She just has to ask forgiveness?”

Alice gave a chuckle. “It's harder for her than you think. She must really mean it. The brush will know when that moment comes.”

When she entered Diane’s dressing room she hesitated and wondered what she was going to tell her friend.

“Did you find her?” Diane’s arm was still in movement, brushing the few patches of hair left. "I can't be seen like this. It's all your fault, how could you do this?” Diane began to berate Tabatha.

The brushing picked up in intensity, the bristles dug into Diane’s scalp, and bubbles of blood began to appear. Worried, Tabatha sat next to her friend, “Diane, the only way this will stop is for you to say you're sorry for the way you have treated me and others; to be really sorry.”

“What?! Sorry for what? I haven’t done anything wrong. This is your fault. You sent me cursed brush! Ow, ouch, this is hurting me.” She cried and reached her hand to the back of her head. When she brought it down to look at it, her palm was streaked with blood. She cried harder.

“Diane, listen to me," Tabatha was frantic, “We've been friends since high school. After you married Phil he was promoted to CEO, you changed. You began to act differently.”

“What are you talking about?” Diane was sobbing, holding a towel to her bleeding scalp with one hand while the other held the brush that continued to stroke her scalp.

“You became obsessed with your looks, had implants, plastic surgery, hair plugs, skin peals and I don’t know what else. I tried to tell you that all this was not the Diane I knew. We volunteered at the shelter for abused women, but you couldn’t be seen there, you just wrote a check for them. We used to do the Walk for the Cure, but you only went when you wore these cute pink outfits and when you were left behind because you were out of shape, you quit. Every time I make an appointment to meet you for lunch, you talk about your latest improvement or where you've traveled. When I try to share what's going on with me, you make excuses and leave.” Tears flowed from Tabatha’s eyes as she watched her friend suffering from the brushing.

Diane stared at the mirror for a long time and then at Tabatha who held her hand.

“I'm a bitch.” Tears filled Diane’s eyes. “I've been totally engrossed with myself.” She dabbed her eyes with the blood speckled towel. “When I married Phil and he was promoted, I felt inadequate; that I wasn’t good enough to associate with the other wives. Now I'm just like them." She cried harder. Tabatha noticed that the brush strokes slowed. “How do you feel about me?”

Diane didn't answer right away. Tabatha could see the war waged on in Diane’s mind. Her expression revealed anger because of the brush and its curse, but love pushed strongly to overcome.

“You did buy me this awful brush,” She accused.

“I didn’t know it was cursed. I felt drawn into this shop compelled to buy the brush. I think I must have been under some kind of spell.” Tabatha whispered, “Maybe fate stepped in to save you.”

“Save me from what?!” Diane shouted, “I'm happy the way I am.” The speed of the brush picked up.

“Are you really? Are you and Phil happy together the way you were when you first married?” Tabatha’s kept her voice low.

“No! I'm not happy, and Phil and I argue all the time.” The words burst out of her like a geyser. “Oh, Tabatha, I'm sorry for the way I treated you.” Diane cried and the strokes slowed again. “I want us to be friends like we were before. To do the things I though were important. I want Phil and I to be happy like when we were first married.” The brush lay limp on her lap unnoticed. "I really am sorry." Diane sobbed in true contrition.

Tabatha reached out and hugged her friend. The brush fell to the floor unheeded.

A year later, Tabatha and Diane walked down the sidewalk from their lunch. “This is where I saw the Museum.” Tabatha pointed and then stopped. There it was. She looked at the businesses on either side and they were the same.

“Let’s go in, I'd love to see what's in there.” She started to the doorway.

“No, believe me you do not want to go in there.” Tabatha took Diane’s arm and steered her down the street.
1553.title: A Silver Hairbrush

15533.content:
I am round.

I am gold.

I am old.

Once I rested comfortably in a place of honor, the worship place of an ancient religion, an inner chamber of a stone temple in an equatorial rain forest. I was an object of veneration and mystery and awe.

Oh, I suppose here on this pedestal in this museum is not without honor, but no one worships me, the mystery is gone, and there is no awe. I miss the awe.

Of course, I know I am only the medallion, not the chameleon. The chameleon exists on a different plane entirely, eternal and unchanging... except when change is the nature of it's existence. Maybe I should say eternally unchanging in its ability to change... but now it's getting too complicated to describe.

Anyway, that's why I am made from gold. It's the material substance that is most eternal and unchanging. Unless you melt me into shapelessness or beat me into a distorted pancake. I hope you won't do that. I guess I should be glad I am in the Museum of Linked Objects, protected from the ravages of time.

Do you know how I got here?
15533.title: Medallion of the Golden Chameleon

choices: a clay crock with gold formed into it
a gem made into the shape of a rose
155332.content:
I am wood crafted from a hardwood tree at the center of the sacred forest. Only those who have the knowledge can find the center. The tree offers its limb for the one whose real need is offered.

The brass is refined from the cave along the path leading away from the forest and will opne only when the wood is laid at the opening and the words from the book are spoken.

When the box is crafted, the finest cloth is inliaid tto fit the form of the precious gift. Then and only then will the brass locks beaten to the finite demention fit perfectly together.

Here I lay closed to only those with the key to open the museum and see me.
155332.title: Mahoghany box with brass hinges

info.brief_description: A linking object is a physical item that connects you to someone in your past.
info.description:
Welcome the the Museum of Linking Objects. In this Museum, you will find physical objects that tie you to a friend, a family member or an important person (living or dead) out of your past, who you have lost contact with. These are things that are in common use today or were in common use at one point in history.

1. The speaker in each chapter: (1) you (the person looking at the item), (2) the person who originally owned/used the item, or (3) the item.

2. Description of Object/Item: This does not have to be a detailed description, but it needs to be described from the point of view of the speaker.

3. Do not use identifying names: Use him/her (when it is a friend) or mother/father, aunt/uncle, brother/sister (when referring to family members).

4. Point of View: First person point view is used at all times.
